title: Lumbar Spinal Stenosis
icd10: M99.23 (Subluxation stenosis of neural canal of lumbar region)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis in adults. Includes diagnostic workup, conservative management, interventional procedures, and surgical referral criteria. Covers ED presentation with acute neurological decline, inpatient perioperative management, and outpatient chronic management. Excludes congenital stenosis, cervical/thoracic stenosis, and cauda equina syndrome as separate entities (though cauda equina is addressed as a red flag).

Core Labs (Preoperative and Baseline).rationale: Preoperative baseline; rule out infection if acute presentation; anemia assessment
Core Labs (Preoperative and Baseline).target: Normal WBC, Hgb >10 g/dL for surgical planning

Core Labs (Preoperative and Baseline).rationale: Electrolytes, renal function; preoperative assessment; NSAID safety
Elevated in infection, malignancy, or inflammatory spondyloarthropathy
Core Labs (Preoperative and Baseline).target: Normal (<20 mm/hr men, <30 mm/hr women); elevated suggests alternative diagnosis

Core Labs (Preoperative and Baseline).rationale: Inflammatory marker; infection screening in acute presentations
Evaluate urinary retention; rule out UTI in patients with bladder complaints
Core Labs (Preoperative and Baseline).target: Normal; post-void residual if retention suspected

Core Labs (Preoperative and Baseline).rationale: Diabetes as comorbidity affecting surgical outcomes and neuropathy overlap

Extended Labs (Selected Patients).rationale: B12 deficiency causing myelopathy or neuropathy mimicking stenosis symptoms
Hypothyroidism causing myopathy or fatigue mimicking claudication
Screen for myeloma or amyloidosis in atypical presentations or pathologic fractures
Preoperative blood bank preparation for surgical patients

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Deficiency common in chronic back pain; affects bone health and surgical fusion outcomes
Copper deficiency myelopathy mimicking stenosis (especially post-gastric bypass)
Confirm functional B12 deficiency if B12 borderline (200-400 pg/mL)

Essential Studies.timing: Within 24h if acute deficit; routine for chronic symptoms
Essential Studies.target: Central canal diameter, lateral recess narrowing, foraminal stenosis, disc herniation, ligamentum flavum hypertrophy; grade stenosis severity

Essential Studies.timing: Initial imaging in ED; assess alignment and instability
Essential Studies.target: Disc space narrowing, osteophytes, spondylolisthesis, alignment; flexion-extension views for dynamic instability

Essential Studies.timing: If bladder dysfunction suspected; cauda equina screening
Essential Studies.target: <100 mL normal; >200 mL suggests neurogenic bladder

Extended Studies.timing: If MRI contraindicated; superior bony detail for surgical planning
Extended Studies.target: Facet hypertrophy, osteophyte dimensions, bony canal diameter; complements MRI for surgical planning

Extended Studies.timing: If concern for infection, tumor, post-surgical recurrence, or arachnoiditis
Extended Studies.target: Enhancement suggesting tumor, infection, or inflammation; post-operative scar vs recurrent herniation

Extended Studies.timing: If radiculopathy localization needed; differentiate from peripheral neuropathy; quantify nerve injury severity
Extended Studies.target: Active denervation in specific myotomal distribution; normal NCS (rules out peripheral neuropathy)
Extended Studies.contraindications: Anticoagulation (relative for needle EMG); skin infection at electrode sites

Extended Studies.timing: If MRI contraindicated and MRI-quality detail needed; dynamic evaluation of stenosis
Extended Studies.target: Contrast filling defects corresponding to stenosis levels; thecal sac compression

Rare/Specialized.timing: Pre-surgical assessment in patients >65 or osteoporosis risk; affects fusion strategy
Rare/Specialized.target: T-score > -2.5; osteoporosis affects screw purchase and fusion rates

Rare/Specialized.timing: Dynamic stenosis evaluation; symptoms worse with standing but MRI supine is borderline
Rare/Specialized.target: Worsening stenosis with axial loading or upright positioning

Rare/Specialized.timing: Identify symptomatic level when multilevel stenosis present and clinical-imaging correlation unclear
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Coagulopathy; infection; allergy to local anesthetic

First-Line Conservative Management.monitoring: LFTs if chronic use >2 weeks; hepatic symptoms

First-Line Conservative Management.indication: All patients as first-line; neurogenic claudication; deconditioning

doseOptions.orderSentence: Physical therapy (flexion-based program) (CPT 97110) 2-3x/week for 6-12 weeks Physical

First-Line Conservative Management.monitoring: Pain levels; walking distance; functional capacity; adherence

First-Line Conservative Management.indication: Moderate-severe neurogenic claudication or radiculopathy; failed 6 weeks conservative treatment; bridge to surgery

First-Line Conservative Management.monitoring: Blood glucose (diabetics) for 1-2 weeks post-injection; neurologic exam; infection signs

Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: BP; hepatic function; serotonin syndrome symptoms; discontinuation syndrome

Second-Line/Refractory.monitoring: Sedation; anticholinergic effects; cardiac monitoring in elderly

Surgical Treatment.indication: Moderate-severe stenosis with neurogenic claudication or radiculopathy refractory to 3-6 months conservative treatment; progressive neurologic deficit

dosing.instructions: Standard posterior decompressive laminectomy; single or multilevel; preserves facet joints when possible

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Medically unfit for surgery; minimal clinical symptoms despite imaging findings
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Post-op neurologic exam; wound healing; DVT prophylaxis; pain management; mobilization

Surgical Treatment.indication: Stenosis with spondylolisthesis (grade >=2); stenosis with significant instability; recurrent stenosis post-prior decompression; scoliosis correction needed

doseOptions.orderSentence: Laminectomy with instrumented fusion (CPT 22630) Elective Surgical

dosing.instructions: Decompression plus posterolateral or interbody fusion with pedicle screw fixation; single or multilevel
dosing.orderSentence: Laminectomy with instrumented fusion (CPT 22630) Elective Surgical

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Same as laminectomy; osteoporosis (relative — may need cement-augmented screws)
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Same as laminectomy plus fusion assessment (CT at 6-12 months); hardware position; pseudarthrosis screening

Surgical Treatment.indication: Mild-moderate neurogenic claudication; patients who may not tolerate open surgery; indirect decompression

dosing.instructions: Minimally invasive insertion; limits extension and indirectly opens spinal canal; ambulatory surgery center eligible

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Severe stenosis (AP diameter <7 mm); spondylolisthesis >grade 1; fixed kyphosis; osteoporosis; spinous process fracture
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Post-procedure imaging; symptom assessment; device position

Surgical Treatment.indication: Moderate stenosis; patients preferring less invasive approach; unilateral or bilateral decompression

doseOptions.orderSentence: Minimally invasive decompression (tubular retractor laminotomy) Elective Surgical

dosing.instructions: Unilateral approach for bilateral decompression; tubular retractor technique; shorter hospitalization; less tissue disruption
dosing.orderSentence: Minimally invasive decompression (tubular retractor laminotomy) Elective Surgical

Surgical Treatment.contraindications: Same as open laminectomy; severe bilateral stenosis may require open approach
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: Same as laminectomy; shorter expected recovery (2-4 weeks vs 4-6 weeks)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurosurgery or spine surgery consultation for cauda equina syndrome (emergent), progressive neurologic deficit, or failure of 3-6 months conservative management
Physical therapy referral for flexion-based exercise program, core stabilization, and aerobic conditioning (stationary cycling, aquatic therapy) — first-line treatment
Pain management/interventional spine referral for epidural steroid injections, diagnostic nerve blocks, or multimodal pain management
PMR (physiatrist) for comprehensive non-operative management plan including activity modification, assistive devices, and rehabilitation
Neurology consultation if peripheral neuropathy overlap suspected or if electrodiagnostic testing needed for localization
Occupational therapy for ADL modification, ergonomic assessment, and adaptive equipment (rolling walker, seated work station)

Patient Instructions.item: Lumbar flexion relieves symptoms: lean forward, push a shopping cart, use a rolling walker, or ride a stationary bicycle to open the spinal canal and reduce nerve compression
Avoid prolonged standing and walking downhill (extension aggravates stenosis); take sitting breaks every 15-30 minutes during walking
Use a rolling walker or shopping cart for longer walks — leaning forward on a support device increases walking distance by reducing spinal canal narrowing

Report immediately to ED if loss of bladder or bowel control, numbness in the groin/perineal area (saddle anesthesia), or sudden onset bilateral leg weakness — these indicate cauda equina syndrome requiring emergency surgery
Take NSAIDs with food to reduce stomach irritation; report any dark stools, stomach pain, or blood in stool immediately
Attend physical therapy consistently; flexion-based exercises and aerobic conditioning are the foundation of treatment and improve walking distance significantly
Understand that imaging findings (MRI stenosis) do not always correlate with symptoms — many people have stenosis on MRI without symptoms; treatment targets symptoms, not pictures
Weight loss (if overweight) reduces spinal loading and may improve symptoms; maintain BMI <30 as a goal

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Perform daily flexion-based exercises: pelvic tilts, knee-to-chest stretches, partial sit-ups, stationary cycling 20-30 minutes; these open the spinal canal and reduce neurogenic claudication
Maintain healthy weight to reduce axial loading on the lumbar spine; target BMI <30
Avoid high-impact activities (running, jumping) and heavy lifting (>25 lbs) which increase disc and facet loading and may worsen stenosis symptoms
Use proper body mechanics: bend at the knees (not waist), avoid twisting while lifting, and maintain neutral spine alignment during activities
Aquatic therapy or pool walking provides exercise with buoyancy support, reducing spinal loading while maintaining cardiovascular fitness
Smoking cessation: smoking impairs blood flow to spinal structures, accelerates disc degeneration, and significantly worsens surgical fusion outcomes
Optimize bone health: calcium 1000-1200 mg/day, vitamin D 1000-2000 IU/day, and DEXA screening if age >65 or osteoporosis risk factors present

differential.features: Calf-predominant pain relieved by standing still (not flexion); diminished pedal pulses; reproducible at same walking distance; does NOT improve with spinal flexion
differential.tests: ABI (ankle-brachial index) <0.9; arterial Doppler ultrasound; CTA of lower extremities

differential.features: Usually unilateral dermatomal pain; positive SLR; worse with flexion/sitting (opposite of stenosis); younger patients
differential.tests: MRI showing disc herniation compressing nerve root; EMG/NCS showing radiculopathy

differential.features: Symmetric stocking-glove sensory loss; burning/tingling; not positional; present at rest; no claudication pattern
differential.tests: EMG/NCS showing length-dependent polyneuropathy; HbA1c; B12 level

differential.features: Groin/lateral hip pain with walking; limited hip ROM (internal rotation); pain with hip flexion-internal rotation; not relieved by spinal flexion
differential.tests: X-ray pelvis/hip showing joint space narrowing, osteophytes; hip ROM exam

differential.features: Lateral hip/thigh pain; point tenderness over greater trochanter; pain with side-lying; not neurogenic claudication pattern
differential.tests: Clinical exam (tenderness over trochanter); normal imaging; ultrasound if needed

differential.features: Acute bilateral leg weakness, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention/incontinence; bowel dysfunction; requires emergent evaluation
differential.tests: Emergent MRI; post-void residual >200 mL; rectal exam (decreased tone)

differential.features: Similar to CES but upper motor neuron signs may be present; symmetric; earlier bladder involvement
differential.tests: MRI showing compression above L1-L2 level; UMN signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski)

differential.features: Gait apraxia (magnetic gait), urinary incontinence, cognitive decline; does not have neurogenic claudication pattern
differential.tests: MRI brain showing ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy; lumbar tap test

differential.features: Progressive symptoms; night pain; constitutional symptoms; not positional relief pattern; may have upper or lower motor neuron signs
differential.tests: MRI with contrast showing enhancing lesion; labs (SPEP, PSA, etc.)

differential.features: Widespread pain; fatigue; tender points; no neurologic deficit; not position-dependent
differential.tests: Clinical diagnosis (2016 criteria); normal MRI; normal EMG/NCS

evidence.recommendation: MRI is the imaging modality of choice for lumbar spinal stenosis
evidence.source: [Defined MRI grading improves correlation with clinical severity](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20881510/)

evidence.recommendation: Physical therapy with flexion-based exercises improves walking distance and function
evidence.source: [Delitto A et al. Ann Intern Med 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25844995/)

evidence.recommendation: Epidural steroid injections provide short-term (2-6 week) pain relief for neurogenic claudication
Surgical decompression is superior to continued conservative treatment for moderate-severe stenosis after 6+ months
Gabapentin reduces radicular pain in spinal stenosis
Walking capacity measured by self-paced walking test is a valid outcome measure for lumbar stenosis
Fusion is recommended when spondylolisthesis accompanies stenosis requiring decompression
NASS Clinical Guidelines for Lumbar Spinal Stenosis
Cauda equina syndrome requires surgical decompression within 24-48 hours for optimal outcomes
Interspinous spacer devices provide non-inferior results to laminectomy for mild-moderate stenosis

monitoring.action: Escalate treatment; consider ESI or surgical referral if declining
Urgent MRI and surgical consultation if new or progressive deficit
Adjust medications; consider interventional or surgical options
Emergent MRI for cauda equina; Foley catheter if >500 mL
Discontinue NSAIDs; switch to acetaminophen or gabapentin
Adjust diabetic medications; close endocrine follow-up
Evaluate for adjacent segment disease, hardware failure, pseudarthrosis

disposition.criteria: No cauda equina syndrome; stable neurologic exam; pain controlled with oral medications; able to ambulate safely; outpatient MRI and follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks
Acute neurologic decline requiring serial exams; pain requiring IV medications; MRI obtained showing severe stenosis awaiting neurosurgical evaluation

Cauda equina syndrome for emergent surgical decompression; progressive motor deficit requiring inpatient workup; elective surgical admission for scheduled decompression/fusion; pain crisis unresponsive to outpatient management
Post-operative complication (epidural hematoma, severe neurologic decline); hemodynamic instability; respiratory compromise in patients with significant comorbidities
New diagnosis: spine surgery or physiatry within 2-4 weeks; post-ESI: 2-4 weeks; post-operative: 2 weeks (wound check), 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months
Chronic management: q3-6 months; medication monitoring (NSAIDs, gabapentin); physical therapy progress; weight management
